sect2.title: Location-Speakers
sect2.para: Varieties and subdialects of Afar are spoken by more than a million individuals in Ethiopia, Djibouti, and Eritrea. It is very closely related to Saho

biblioset.title: Appendix A: A Concise Outline of Phonology and Morphology

publisher.publishername: School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London

sect1.title: Paradigm Lexemes
sect1.para:
The following lexical items are used in the verbal paradigms:
lemma gloss properties
ab- do conjClass=suffix, pos=verb
anày-ʕunɗa- be softly spoken conjClass=compoundStative, pos=verb
eeɗeg- know conjClass=prefix, pos=verb
fak- open conjClass=suffix, pos=verb
kàɗ-hee bow conjClass=compoundTransitive, pos=verb
le- have conjClass=stativeIrreg, pos=verb
meʕ- be good conjClass=stative, pos=verb
ruffa-eɗḥ- become happy conjClass=compoundIntransitive, pos=verb
uduur- return conjClass=prefix, pos=verb

sect1.title: Morphosyntactic Properties
sect1.para: Afar paradigms employ the following property-value dimenstions

listitem.para: Afar follows the Cushitic-Omotic PNG Pattern.

case: Afar follows the Cushitic-Omotic Pattern. In addition there is a reflexive pronoun and an emphatic foregrounding pronoun. Both the possessive and the emphatic occur with what Hayward 1985 terms "m-nominalizations" (p. 236) which can frequently be glossed "the ones/things pertaining-to/belonging-to".

conjClass: In addition to the old Afroasiatic distinction between regular prefixing and suffixing conjugation class verbs, as found in Beja and in the Omo-Tana languages, within the suffixing verbs, Afar distinguishes a distinct stative subclass.There are in addition three suffixing classes of compound verbs consisting of an invariant first element: and a specially conjugated second verb element. Finally, there is the characteristic small inventory of "special" verbs.
compoundStative: Invariant+ʕunɗ- ; paradigm lexeme anày-ʕunɗ- "be soft-spoken"
Possessive: le- (also used to form the future)

theme: The semantic, lexical, and formal variety of what Hayward 1985 (pp. 243-252) calls "extended stem (ES)" verbs is, as Hayward says (p. 245), with some understatement, "very considerable." The usual major categories occur, with many combinations, permutations, and variants, and has not lent itself to simple paradigmatic treatment. See the extensive "Table 16" with notes in Hayward 1985 (pp. 245-251).

General Characteristics: Afar, in the detailed analysis of Hayward 1985, displays a complex interaction between simple and compound, affirmative and negative tense-aspect properties and values.The following table (a slight adaptation of the paradigm afar-VTAMStemStructure) gives the main verb stem structure and the structure of the auxiliaries and/or adjuncts, affirmative and negative, for each of the 26 tam forms recognized by Hayward. Note that what Hayward calls the perfect/imperfect participle is simply the perfect/imperfect form of the verb with a suffix -h, which in many cases may be roughly paraphrased as "(NP) having V-ed"; the same suffix -h can occur optionally with the main verb in clauses in which the verbal-predicate, as opposed to a nominal constituent, is being foregrounded. Among the main verb adjuncts are a number of invariant words/clitics; and the conjugated auxiliaries: the prefixing verb -en- 'be', and the suffixing sug- 'stay, wait', wa- ' ', and ɗaaɗ - ' ' , In the absence of a detailed analysis, an approximate gloss (that of Hayward, in fact) is given for the affirmative forms. As example of each polarity-tam comination we give the 3msg form of the suffixing verb fak- 'open'.:

tr.td: he opens / is opening / will open
he was /had been opening / used to open
he was /had been opening / used to open
he is intending / about to open
if he had opened / had he opened

listitem.para: simple: As can be seen from the table, in the affirmative only the imperative/jussive/requestive can be said to be truly non-compound, and the perfect/imperfect marginally so, in that a -h adjunct can be dropped if the verb is not the foregrounded element in a clause. In the negative, only the imperfect and the requestive/imperative occur without adjuncts.

sect1.title: Attested Archive Paradigms
sect1.para:
The following two tables give the feature-value combinations of the paradigms wich are actually documented in the archive. The first simply lists the shared property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The second listing gives a spreadsheet-like row-by-column enumeration for the properties which are common to each paradigm; this eventually should be user-sortable to facilitate the comparative study of the paradigms. The second simply lists the common property=value pairs for each paradigm, and then the variable property=value-list (comma separated). The abbreviation "PNG" in the paradigm variable-value lists stnads for:
gender:f,m,⊤ number:pl,sg person:p1,p2,p3
I.e., the PNG combinations normal with finite tam-forms.Clicking on the paradigmLabel will yield a display of the paradigm in question [either by link to hard-coded term cluster, or canned SPARQL query].

table.caption: Table 1: Prop:Val List of Default Paradigms
